nexttext:
\noindent
where $r$ and $\phi$ are transverse plane coordinates, $w_0$ is the beam waist radius at the pupil and  $L_p^{|l|}(.)$ is the generalized Laguerre polynomial.

This mode is projected on to a possibly different conjugate LG mode $LG_{p',l'}^{*}$ using the phase SLM. The chosen beam waist radius of this conjugate mode gives the $w_0$ for the decomposition of the unknown incoming beam. The resulting field is Fourier-transformed in the focal plane of lens B. The phase SLM is placed in the front focal plane of lens B, so that the field in the back focal plane of lens B is given by an exact Fourier transform. The field in the back focal plane of lens B is then given by \cite{Qassim:14}:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="LG_{p,l}(r,\phi)=\sqrt{\frac{2^{|l|+1}p!}{\pi w_{0}^{2}(p+|l|)!}}\left(\frac{r%
}{w_{0}}\right)^{|l|}e^{-\frac{r^{2}}{w_{0}^{2}}}L_{p}^{|l|}\left(\frac{2r^{2}%
}{w_{0}^{2}}\right)e^{-il\phi}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>G</mi><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msqrt><mfrac><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">!</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>w</mi><mn>0</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">!</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></msqrt><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mi>r</mi><msub><mi>w</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mfrac><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><msubsup><mi>w</mi><mn>0</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mfrac></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>L</mi><mi>p</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><msubsup><mi>w</mi><mn>0</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ϕ</mi></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\noindent
where $\mathcal{FT}$ stands for the Fourier transform and $\rho$ and $\varphi$ are the transverse coordinates in this plane. If we get a mode match with the incoming beam i.e. $p=p'$ and $l=l'$, the Fourier transform gives a central bright Gaussian-like beam in this plane. Otherwise, we do not get a central maximum and the beam cannot couple into the SMF as our simulations later show. Some examples of what the beam looks like in this plane when there is a mode match are given in Ref. \cite{Qassim:14}, Fig. 1 for different values of $p$ and $l$. Some power moves to the outer rings as both $p$ and $|l|$ increase. The power present in the higher order rings cannot couple into the SMF.

The pinhole placed in the focal plane of lens B, truncates the field at the first zero (see Fig. \ref{fig:fig2}) and allows only the central Gaussian-like region to pass through. The size of the pinhole needs to be variable to cater for different modes and $w_0$'s chosen for the decomposition. Hence, we use an amplitude SLM functioning as this variable sized pinhole. Besides constant parameters such as the wavelength of light $\lambda$ and the focal length of lens B, $f_B$, the radius of this variable-sized pinhole, $s$, completely depends upon the $p$ and $l$ values of the mode under consideration and the $w_0$ chosen for the decomposition and is therefore, set in conjunction with the phase SLM. The field after the amplitude SLM is given by:
prevtext:
\noindent
where $r$ and $\phi$ are transverse plane coordinates, $w_0$ is the beam waist radius at the pupil and  $L_p^{|l|}(.)$ is the generalized Laguerre polynomial.

This mode is projected on to a possibly different conjugate LG mode $LG_{p',l'}^{*}$ using the phase SLM. The chosen beam waist radius of this conjugate mode gives the $w_0$ for the decomposition of the unknown incoming beam. The resulting field is Fourier-transformed in the focal plane of lens B. The phase SLM is placed in the front focal plane of lens B, so that the field in the back focal plane of lens B is given by an exact Fourier transform. The field in the back focal plane of lens B is then given by \cite{Qassim:14}:

nexttext:
The resulting field $E_0$ then propagates through two variable focus lenses with focal lengths $f_1$ and $f_2$ to couple into the SMF. Ideal coupling into the SMF depends on matching both the size of the beam and its phase curvature to that of the SMF mode. We, therefore, need to have two independent parameters that we can vary in order to control both the size and phase curvature of the beam. In this case, these two parameters are $f_1$ and $f_2$. The field at the SMF is given by repeated application of the Fresnel diffraction integral.  For example, if the field just before lens C is given by $E_1(x',y')$, where $x'$ and $y'$ are transverse plane coordinates, then the field $E_2(x,y)$ just after lens D, where $x$ and $y$ are transverse plane coordinates, is given by \cite{Goodman:05}:
\begin{widetext}
prevtext:
\noindent
where $\mathcal{FT}$ stands for the Fourier transform and $\rho$ and $\varphi$ are the transverse coordinates in this plane. If we get a mode match with the incoming beam i.e. $p=p'$ and $l=l'$, the Fourier transform gives a central bright Gaussian-like beam in this plane. Otherwise, we do not get a central maximum and the beam cannot couple into the SMF as our simulations later show. Some examples of what the beam looks like in this plane when there is a mode match are given in Ref. \cite{Qassim:14}, Fig. 1 for different values of $p$ and $l$. Some power moves to the outer rings as both $p$ and $|l|$ increase. The power present in the higher order rings cannot couple into the SMF.

The pinhole placed in the focal plane of lens B, truncates the field at the first zero (see Fig. \ref{fig:fig2}) and allows only the central Gaussian-like region to pass through. The size of the pinhole needs to be variable to cater for different modes and $w_0$'s chosen for the decomposition. Hence, we use an amplitude SLM functioning as this variable sized pinhole. Besides constant parameters such as the wavelength of light $\lambda$ and the focal length of lens B, $f_B$, the radius of this variable-sized pinhole, $s$, completely depends upon the $p$ and $l$ values of the mode under consideration and the $w_0$ chosen for the decomposition and is therefore, set in conjunction with the phase SLM. The field after the amplitude SLM is given by:

\noindent
where $d$ is the separation between the lenses, $\lambda$ is the wavelength of the light and $k=2\pi /\lambda$. In the same way, the field $E_1$ starting from the field $E_0$ at the pinhole and the field $E_3$ at the SMF starting from the field $E_2$ after lens D may be calculated.

The power coupled into the SMF is given by the overlap integral of the incoming field $E_3$ with that of the fiber mode which can be approximated by a Gaussian. The coupling efficiency is then given by \cite{Molina-Terriza:07}:
prevtext:
The resulting field $E_0$ then propagates through two variable focus lenses with focal lengths $f_1$ and $f_2$ to couple into the SMF. Ideal coupling into the SMF depends on matching both the size of the beam and its phase curvature to that of the SMF mode. We, therefore, need to have two independent parameters that we can vary in order to control both the size and phase curvature of the beam. In this case, these two parameters are $f_1$ and $f_2$. The field at the SMF is given by repeated application of the Fresnel diffraction integral.  For example, if the field just before lens C is given by $E_1(x',y')$, where $x'$ and $y'$ are transverse plane coordinates, then the field $E_2(x,y)$ just after lens D, where $x$ and $y$ are transverse plane coordinates, is given by \cite{Goodman:05}:
\begin{widetext}

class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\iint</mtext></merror><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo nexttext:
\noindent
where $\sigma$ is the beam waist radius of the SMF mode.

To find the values of the focal lengths, $f_1$ and $f_2$, of the two variable focus lenses in order to maximally couple the field $E_1$ after the pinhole into the SMF, we use the ABCD matrix approach \cite{Kogelnik:66}. The field $E_1$ can be approximated with a Gaussian with radius $w_1$ taken to be the point where the field drops to $1/e$ of its maximum value. Just like the size of the pinhole $s$, $w_1$ is also completely determined by $p$, $l$ and $w_0$. The $q$-parameter \cite{Kogelnik:66} of this input Gaussian is then given by:
prevtext:
\end{widetext}
\noindent
where $d$ is the separation between the lenses, $\lambda$ is the wavelength of the light and $k=2\pi /\lambda$. In the same way, the field $E_1$ starting from the field $E_0$ at the pinhole and the field $E_3$ at the SMF starting from the field $E_2$ after lens D may be calculated.

The power coupled into the SMF is given by the overlap integral of the incoming field $E_3$ with that of the fiber mode which can be approximated by a Gaussian. The coupling efficiency is then given by \cite{Molina-Terriza:07}:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\eta_{c}=\frac{\frac{2}{\pi\sigma^{2}}\left|\iint\limits_{-\infty}^{\infty}E_{%
3}(x,y)e^{-\frac{x^{2}+y^{2}}{\sigma^{2}}}\,dx\,dy\right|^{2}}{{\iint\limits_{%
-\infty}^{\infty}\left|E_{3}(x,y)\right|^{2}}\,dx\,dy}" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>η</mi><mi>c</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mrow><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>σ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo>|</mo><mrow><msubsup><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\iint</mtext></merror><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><msup><mi>σ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac></mrow></msup></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><msubsup><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\iint</mtext></merror><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mrow><mo>|</mo><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>

The field $E_1$ can be approximated with a Gaussian with radius $w_1$ taken to be the point where the field drops to $1/e$ of its maximum value. Just like the size of the pinhole $s$, $w_1$ is also completely determined by $p$, $l$ and $w_0$. The $q$-parameter \cite{Kogelnik:66} of this input Gaussian is then given by:

where $d_1$ is the distance from the pinhole to lens C and $d_2$ is the distance from lens D to the SMF. The $q$-parameter of the beam at the fiber needs to conform to the beam waist radius of the fiber mode, $\sigma$ and is then given by:
